newsitem.title: KENYA: Coffee prices rise in Tanzania, steady in Kenya.
newsitem.headline: Coffee prices rise in Tanzania, steady in Kenya.

text.p: Coffee prices for mild arabicas rose in Tanzania and were fully steady in Kenya, traders said.
Quality remained high in Tanzania and Kenya's fly crop was very good for the time of year.
Traders in Nairobi said premium grade AAs fetched around $154 per 50 kg on Tuesday while ABs fetched around $160, which was around $29 and $34 above New York March.
"Coffee will continue to be very expensive. The Coffee Board (of Kenya) has just announced that it does not have much coffee, which will increase market pressure," a trader said.
An official from a leading brokerage house added, "The coffee was expensive. I still think the quality is good for this time of the year. This has not been a bad fly crop at all."
The Coffee Board of Kenya said it sold all 22,493 60 kg bags it had on offer, against the 21,792 sold last week.
Traders said there was coffee at least for two more auctions.
"At the moment it is still open but we are likely to receive the main crop in December, the earliest in many years. So quality should start looking up," a trader said.
Another trader said the market was fully steady and had risen compared to New York despite expectations of a fall.
"It seems there is more demand and quantities are becoming less so prices are up," he said.
Kenya Coffee Auctions Ltd said grade AAs averaged $148 per 50-kg bag bag from $149.50 last week, grade ABs averaged $141 from $141.5 last week, while grade Cs gained $8.5 to stand at $141 on Tuesday.
"The market appears to have become steady after recent advances," an auction official said.
In the northern Tanzanian coffee town of Moshi, traders said Tanzanian AA and AB grades sold at high prices at the auction last Thursday, while lower grades followed world market prices.
A total of 33,223 60-kg bags of mild washed arabicas and 11,256 bags of robusta were sold at the auction.
Tanzania holds coffee export auctions twice a month.

"Thursday was one of the most incredible days at the auction. The highest prices for mild arabicas grade AA sold at $165 per 50 kg bag," a trader said. Lower grades sold at prices averaging between $117 and $159.20 per 50 kg.

Tanzania Coffee Board statistics showed northern arabica prices at $125 per 50 kg for premium AAs and $124 per 50 kg for ABs at the previous auction on October 3. It showed prices for lower grades at $75-107.

"Prices are going to remain fairly constant. Differentials are not falling as expected. That won't happen -- most likely differentials will go up but we can't really predict the New York prices," a senior trader in Moshi told Reuters.
Coffee is measured in 60 kg bags but sold in 50 kg units.
The trader attributed the top prices for Tanzania's premier grades to a general shortage among buyers in the world market for mild arabicas in addition to improvements in quality.
--Nairobi Newsroom +254-2 330-261
